{{Infobox book |name = Brain on Fire: My Month of Madness |image = Brain on Fire Susannah Cahalan.jpg |caption = First edition hardback cover |author = [[Susannah Cahalan]] |title_orig = <!-- if not in English --> |translator = |illustrator = |cover_artist = |country = United States |language = English |series = |subject = [[Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis]] |genre = [[Autobiography]] |published = 2012, Free Press |media_type = Print, e-book, audiobook |pages = 288 pages |isbn = 9781451621372 |oclc = |dewey = |congress = |wikisource = }} '''''Brain on Fire: My Month of Madness''''' is a 2012 [[New York Times Bestselling]] [[autobiography]] by ''[[New York Post]]'' writer [[Susannah Cahalan]]. The book details Cahalan's struggle with a rare [[autoimmune disease]] and her recovery.<ref>{{cite web|last=Couric |first=Katie |title=Brain on Fire: Susannah Cahalan’s Medical Mystery |url=http://katiecouric.com/videos/brain-on-fire-susannah-cahalans-medical-mystery/ |publisher=KatieCouric.com |accessdate=January 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108113621/http://katiecouric.com/videos/brain-on-fire-susannah-cahalans-medical-mystery/ |archivedate=January 8, 2014 |df= }}</ref> It was first published on November 13, 2012 through [[Free Press (publisher)|Free Press]] in hardback, and was later reprinted in paperback by [[Simon & Schuster]] after the two companies merged.
==Synopsis== The book narrates Cahalan's issues with [[anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis]] and the process by which she was diagnosed with this form of [[encephalitis]]. She wakes up in a hospital with no memory of the events of the previous month, during which time she would have violent episodes and delusions. Her eventual diagnosis is made more difficult by various physicians misdiagnosing her with several theories such as "partying too much" and [[schizoaffective disorder]].<ref name=oprah>{{cite web|last=Kahn |first=Jennifer |title=Under Attack: One Woman's Terrifying Battle With an Auto-Immune Disease |url=http://www.oprah.com/health/Susannah-Cahalan-Interview-Brain-on-Fire |publisher=Oprah |accessdate=January 8, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131026000343/http://www.oprah.com/health/Susannah-Cahalan-Interview-Brain-on-Fire |archivedate=October 26, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Eventually several physicians, including Dr. [[Souhel Najjar]], began to suspect that Cahalan was suffering from an [[autoimmune disease]].<ref name=oprah/> Najjar diagnosed Cahalan using a test that involved her drawing a clock, a test normally given to people suspected of having [[dementia]] or [[Alzheimer's disease]].<ref name=pt>{{cite web|last=Forman MD |first=Howard |title=Brain on Fire: An Interview With Susannah Cahalan on Anti–NMDA Receptor Autoimmune Encephalitis |url=http://www.psychiatrictimes.com/film-and-book-reviews/brain-fire-interview-susannah-cahalan-anti%E2%80%93nmda-receptor-autoimmune-encephalitis |newspaper=[[Psychiatric Times]] |date=January 23, 2013 |accessdate=January 8, 2014 |archivedate=July 5, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705110220/http://www.psychiatrictimes.com/film-and-book-reviews/brain-fire-interview-susannah-cahalan-anti%E2%80%93nmda-receptor-autoimmune-encephalitis |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Rather than drawing the clock face normally, the disease caused Cahalan to draw all of the numbers 1 through 12 on the right face of the clock, because the right side of her brain, which regulates the left side of the body, was inflamed. Najjar used this to help diagnose Cahalan and start her road to recovery.<ref>Cahalan, ''Brain on Fire: My Month of Madness'', pp. 131-33.</ref>
The book also covers Cahalan's life after her recovery, including her reactions to watching videotapes of her psychotic episodes while in the hospital. Cahalan also discusses her symptoms prior to her hospitalization, as she had previously been diagnosed by a psychiatrist with [[bipolar disorder]].<ref name=oprah/> While researching, she learned that the disease had only been discovered three years before she became ill.<ref>{{cite web|last=Edemariam |first=Aida |title=Brain on Fire by Susannah Cahalan - review |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/jan/24/brain-fire-susannah-cahalan-review |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=January 24, 2013 |accessdate=July 7, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714231556/http://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/jan/24/brain-fire-susannah-cahalan-review |deadurl=no |archivedate=July 14, 2014 |df= }}</ref> Her research indicated that in 2009 most people with the disease were either misdiagnosed or undiagnosed. Cahalan was fortunate to be correctly diagnosed because, according to Najjar's estimates, only 10 percent of people with the disease were properly diagnosed at that time.<ref>Cahalan, ''Brain on Fire: My Month of Madness'', pp. 221-27.</ref> Since then, a better understanding of the disease and its symptoms has resulted in more frequent diagnosis and treatment.
==Reception== Critical reception for ''Brain on Fire'' has been mostly positive. [[NPR]] commented that the author was "a naturally talented prose stylist" and that "she perfectly tempers her brutal honesty with compassion and something like vulnerability."<ref>{{cite news|last=Schaub |first=Michael |title='Brain On Fire' Details An Out-Of-Mind Experience |url=https://www.npr.org/2012/11/14/164400198/brain-on-fire-details-an-out-of-mind-experience |work=[[NPR]] |date=November 14, 2012 |accessdate=January 8, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720074459/http://www.npr.org/2012/11/14/164400198/brain-on-fire-details-an-out-of-mind-experience |deadurl=no |archivedate=July 20, 2014 |df= }}</ref> The ''[[Washington Post]]'' praised Cahalan's researching abilities for the book, as they noted that she had to rely on information from others, including family members and medical documents.<ref>{{cite web|last=Scarf|first=Maggie|title=‘Brain on Fire: My Month of Madness’ by Susannah Cahalan|date=January 12, 2013|accessdate=January 8, 2014|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/brain-on-fire-my-month-of-madness-by-susannah-cahalan/2013/01/12/d5e5ffcc-43c3-11e2-9648-a2c323a991d6_story.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]}}</ref>
==Film adaptation== In May 2014, it was announced that the book was being adapted into [[Brain on Fire (film)|a film of the same name]] starring [[Chloë Grace Moretz]]<ref>Kit, Borys (June 26, 2015). [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/chloe-grace-moretz-star-brain-805285 "Chloe Grace Moretz to Star in 'Brain on Fire' (Exclusive)"]. ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''.</ref> and produced by Cahalan and [[Charlize Theron]].<ref>{{cite news|date=May 2, 2014 |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/english/hollywood/news-interviews/Dakota-Fanning-to-star-in-Charlize-Therons-Brain-On-Fire/articleshow/34538935.cms |title=Dakota Fanning to star in Charlize Theron's 'Brain On Fire' |newspaper=[[The Times of India]] |accessdate=May 30, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/news/a568649/dakota-fanning-to-star-in-brain-on-fire-adaptation.html#~oFHJvu6NJkV3lO |title=Dakota Fanning to star in Brain On Fire adaptation |publisher=[[Digital Spy]] |author=Zeba Blay |date=May 3, 2014 |accessdate=May 30, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504023531/http://www.digitalspy.com/movies/news/a568649/dakota-fanning-to-star-in-brain-on-fire-adaptation.html#~oFHJvu6NJkV3lO |deadurl=no |archivedate=May 4, 2014 |df= }}</ref> The film was released on [[Netflix]] on June 22, 2018.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.netflix.com/title/80128245 |publisher=Netflix.com |accessdate=May 27, 2018 |deadurl=no |title=Brain on Fire }}</ref>

In [[legal research]], a '''citator''' is a [[citation index]] of legal resources, one of the best-known of which in the [[United States]] is [[Shepard's Citations]]. Given a reference of a legal decision, a citator allows the researcher to find newer documents which cite the original document and thus to reconstruct the judicial history of cases and statutes. Using a citator in this way is [[colloquially]] referred to as "Shepardizing".
==Use in legal research== ===Topical research=== Because cases cite related cases, citators can be used to find cases which are on topics related to a given topic. A common research strategy is to use "one good case" to find related cases.
===Establishing authority=== Another important application is to determine whether the conclusions of one case have been followed, overturned, or modified in later cases, especially by higher courts. This is important for legal systems in which the binding authority of a case is contingent on [[precedent]].
Citators often include annotations indicating the history and treatment of a case in citing opinions. Shepard's notes 'history' as '''a'''ffirmed, '''m'''odified, '''r'''eversed, '''s'''ame case, '''S'''uperseded, or '''v'''acated; and 'treatment' as '''c'''riticised, '''d'''istinguished, '''e'''xplained, '''j''' dissenting opinion, '''~''' consenting opinion, '''L'''imited, '''o'''verruled, or '''q'''uestioned.
Although originally distributed only as printed and bound volumes, citators are now typically on-line services such as [[LexisNexis]]'s online ''Shepard's Citations'', Justis Publishing's provider-neutral [[JustCite]], [[Westlaw]]'s KeyCite, [[Bloomberg Law]]'s BCite, and the Oxford Law Citator of [[Oxford University Press]].
==History==
Citation indexes to the Bible date to the 13th century.<ref>see [[Citation index]] article.</ref>
In English legal literature, volumes of judicial reports included lists of cases cited in that volume starting with ''Raymond's Reports'' (1743) and followed by ''Douglas's Reports'' (1783). Simon Greenleaf (1821) published an alphabetical list of cases with notes on later decisions affecting the precedential authority of the original decision.<ref name='shapiro'/>
The first true citation index dates to the 1860 publication of Labatt's ''Table of Cases...California...'', followed in 1872 by Wait's ''Table of Cases...New York...''. But the most important and best-known citation index came with the 1873 publication of [[Shepard's Citations]].<ref name='shapiro'>Fred R. Shapiro, "Origins of Bibliometrics, Citation Indexing, and Citation Analysis: The Neglected Legal Literature" ''Journal of the American Society of Information Science'' '''43''':5:337-339 (1992)</ref>
Frank Shepard Company started publishing citators in New York City in 1873 and other companies provided similar services at around the same time, ''e.g.'' George Fred Williams's ''Massachusetts citations: a table of cases, overruled, denied, doubted, criticised, approved, and cited by the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court|Supreme Judicial Court]]'' (Boston, 1878).
The name 'citator' appears to have been coined by the Citator Publishing Company (Detroit) in 1908 in ''The Citator: an annotated compilation of citations of the [[Kansas Supreme Court]]...''.
==Further reading== *"Mastering The Lawless Science Of Our Law: A Story Of Legal Citation Indexes." Patti Ogden, Law Library Journal Winter 1993 (85 Law Libr. J. 1) *"Citators: Past, Present, and Future." Laura C. Dabney, Legal Reference Services Quarterly 27 (2-3), 2004 (27 L. Reference Servs. Q. 165)

'''Doriscus''' ({{lang-gr|Δορίσκος}}) was an ancient settlement in [[Thrace]] (modern-day [[Greece]]), on the northern shores of [[Aegean Sea]]. It was notable for remaining in [[Achaemenid Empire|Persia]]n hands for many years after the [[Second Persian invasion of Greece]], and remained thus known as the last Persian stronghold in [[Europe]].<ref>Raymond A. Bowman. [https://books.google.nl/books?id=DGViAAAAMAAJ&q=doriscus+persian+stronghold+europe&dq=doriscus+persian+stronghold+europe&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0CCoQ6AEwAGoVChMI0amIxbqCyQIVxRYPCh2LYAUx ''Aramaic Ritual Texts from Persepolis''] Vol.'''91''' [[University of Chicago Press]], 1970, p. 61.</ref><ref name="blunsom13">{{cite book| first=E. O. | last=Blunsom | url=https://books.google.nl/books?id=9OmzcuGNJUgC&pg=PA101&dq=doriscus+persian+garrison&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAGoVChMIpNuaqrCCyQIVxLsPCh27UwxM#v=onepage&q=doriscus%20persian%20garrison&f=false | title=The Past and Future of Law | publisher=[[Xlibris Corporation]] | date=10 April 2013 | isbn=978-1462875160 | page=101 }}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}</ref>
The ancient city was located in a vast plain of the same name, where the [[Maritsa|River Hebrus]] was crossing in the middle.
The city fell into the Persian hands without any resistance, during the [[Darius the Great]]' [[European Scythian campaign of Darius I|Scythian Expedition]] and inclusion of the [[Black Sea]] territories into the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian Empire]], around 522 BCE.<ref>Amelie Kuhrt. ''The Persian Empire: A Corpus of Sources from the Achaemenid Period'', Routledge (2007), p. 209.</ref> He built a Royal Fortress and stationed a large number of Persian troops there.
[[Herodotus]] (7.59) reports that [[Xerxes I of Persia|Xerxes the Great]], during his [[Second Persian invasion of Greece|campaign]] of invading the [[Polis|Greek City States]] in 480 BCE, was the first place he stopped to review his troops after crossing the [[Hellespont]].<ref>Christopher J. Tuplin, Xerxes' March from Doriscus to Therme, ''Historia: Zeitschrift für Alte Geschichte'', Bd 52, H. 4 (2003), pp. 385–409.</ref>
[[Herodotus]] also writes that Xerxes I of Persia made [[Mascames]], son of [[Megadostes]], governor of Doriscus in order to replace the man [[Darius I]] had appointed.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Herodotus]]|title=The Histories|date=2008|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|location=[[Great Clarendon Street]], Oxford|isbn=978-0-19-953566-8|page=441}}</ref>
Doriscus is notable as it was one of the few Persian towns in the [[Balkans]] that remained under the Persian sway, even after the [[Second Persian invasion of Greece]].<ref name="blunsom13" /> The Athenian general [[Cimon]] that led the conquests after the Persian retreat was unable to capture it. Herodotus states that Doriscus "was never taken" from the Persians.<ref name="blunsom13" /> Its governor Mascamos was honored by the Persian king for his defence.<ref name="blunsom13" />

{{unreferenced|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox organization |image = |logo = [[File:EPIC logo 2017.png|center|alt=EPIC logo]] |formation = {{start date and age|1994}} |type = [[501(c)(3) nonprofit organization]] |purpose = [[privacy]], [[freedom of expression]], democratic values, [[open government]] |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = [[Marc Rotenberg]] | name = Electronic Privacy Information Center |website = {{URL|epic.org}} |location = 1718 Connecticut Ave NW, Suite 200, [[Washington, D.C.]], U.S. 20009 |abbreviation = EPIC }} '''Electronic Privacy Information Center''' ('''EPIC''') is an independent [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] research center in [[Washington, D.C.]] EPIC's mission is to focus public attention on emerging [[privacy]] and related [[human rights]] issues. EPIC works to protect [[privacy]], [[Freedom of Expression|freedom of expression]], and democratic values, and to promote the Public Voice in decisions concerning the future of the Internet.
EPIC is involved with wide range of civil liberties, consumer protection, and human rights issues. EPIC has pursued several successful consumer privacy complaints with the [[Federal Trade Commission|US Federal Trade Commission]], concerning [[Snapchat]] (faulty privacy technology), [[WhatsApp]] (privacy policy after acquisition by Facebook), [[Facebook]] (changes in user privacy settings), [[Google]] (roll-out of Google Buzz), [[Microsoft]] (Hailstorm log-in), and [[LexisNexis Risk Solutions|Choicepoint]] (sale of personal information to identity thieves). EPIC has also prevailed in significant [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] cases against the CIA, the DHS, the Dept. of Education, the FBI, the NSA, the ODNI, and the TSA. EPIC has also filed many "friend of the court" briefs on law and technology, including [[Riley v. California]] (U.S. 2014) (concerning cell phone privacy), and litigated important privacy cases, including [https://epic.org/privacy/litigation/apa/tsa/bodyscanner/ EPIC v. DHS] (D.C. Cir. 2011), which led to the removal of the x-ray body scanners in US airports, and [https://epic.org/privacy/nsa/epic_v_nsa.html EPIC v. NSA] (D.C. Cir. 2014), which led to the release of the NSA's formerly secret [[cybersecurity]] authority. EPIC also challenged the NSA's domestic [[surveillance]] program in a petition to the US Supreme Court. [https://epic.org/privacy/nsa/in-re-epic/ In re EPIC], (U.S. 2013) after the release of the "Verizon Order" in June 2013. One of EPIC's current [https://epic.org/privacy/litigation/apa/faa/drones/ cases] concerns the obligation of the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] to establish privacy regulations prior to the deployment of commercial drones in the United States.
EPIC works closely with a distinguished advisory board, with expertise in law, technology and public policy.
Based in Washington, D.C., EPIC engages the national debate over the future of privacy. With an office in Somerville, Massachusetts, EPIC works on state and local issues across the country. And with strong ties to organizations around the world, EPIC has a global presence.
== EPIC program areas ==
=== EPIC Open Government project === The [https://epic.org/open_gov/ EPIC Open Government Project] is one of the nation's leading government transparency programs. Combining decades of expertise in the Freedom of Information Act with experienced litigation attorneys, EPIC obtains important government records to promote accountability and safeguard civil liberties.
The EPIC Open Government Project pursues four distinct program activities. First, the project actively pursues secret government documents through the FOIA. Second, the EPIC Open Government Project recommends improvements to agency rulemakings concerning transparency, privacy, and civil liberties. Third, EPIC trains law school students on utilizing the FOIA to promote open government. Fourth, EPIC participates in coalitions with other government transparency organizations. EPIC's extensive press outreach and popular website allow EPIC to make FOIA documents widely available to the press and the public.
=== Public Voice project === The [http://thepublicvoice.org Public Voice] coalition was established in 1996 by EPIC to promote public participation in decisions concerning the future of the Internet. The Public Voice has pursued issues ranging from privacy and freedom of expression to consumer protection and Internet governance. Through international conferences, reports and funding for travel the Public Voice project seeks to increase the presence of NGOs at meetings across the globe. In cooperation with the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]], [[UNESCO]], and other international organizations, the Public Voice project brings civil society leaders face to face with government officials for constructive engagement about current policy issues. Public Voice events have been held in Buenos Aires, Cancun, Cape Town, Dubai, Hong Kong, Honolulu, Kuala Lumpur, Madrid, Ottawa, Paris, Seoul, Washington, and Wroclaw.
The Public Voice project is made possible, in part, by support from the [[Ford Foundation]], the [[Markle Foundation]], the [[Open Society Foundations|Open Society Institute]], and EPIC. The Public Voice has provided support for several organizations, including the Center for International Media Action, CPSR, [[EDRi]], [[People for Internet Responsibility]], [[Privacy International]], CPSR-Peru, and the [[Trans Atlantic Consumer Dialogue|TransAlantic Consumer Dialogue]] (TACD).
The Public Voice helped establish the [http://csisac.org Civil Society Information Society Advisory Council] (CSISAC) which is the "voice of civil society" at the OECD. CSISAC's mission is set out in the Seoul Declaration adopted at the OECD Ministerial Meeting in Seoul, 2008. CSISAC contributes to the OECD's work on Digital Economy Policy and promotes the exchange of information between the OECD and civil society. The OECD provides civil society participants with substantial empirical analysis that enable informed policy assessments; CSISAC provides the OECD with the essential perspectives of experts and NGOs leaders. CSISAC strengthens the relationship between civil society and the OECD and promotes better-informed and more widely accepted policies for the IT sector.
"There is an increasing recognition that we must involve all stakeholders including the voice of civil society. The Public Voice meeting and its contributions to the Forum have been constructive and positive."—OECD Under Secretary General
=== EPIC Amicus project === The [https://epic.org/amicus/ EPIC Amicus Project] seeks to promote privacy and government oversight by filing "friend of the court" briefs in federal and state courts. The EPIC Amicus Program is one of the most prolific appellate advocacy programs in the United States, filing almost 100 amicus briefs on emerging privacy and civil liberties issues, including more than 20 briefs for the [[Supreme Court of the United States|US Supreme Court]]. The EPIC Project brings together experts in the fields of law, technology, and privacy policy with a team of in-house litigators to identify and file in cutting edge privacy cases. EPIC's amicus briefs have been cited by judges and justices in significant Fourth Amendment, consumer privacy, communications privacy, medical privacy, workplace privacy, and open government cases. EPIC continues to expand the scope of the Amicus Program, including arguing cases before the [[Supreme Court of New Jersey|New Jersey Supreme Court]], the [[New Mexico Supreme Court]], and the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit|U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit]]. EPIC's amicus participation has also been requested by judges in both federal and state cases. And EPIC attorneys frequently speak at judicial conferences, both in the United States and around the world, about emerging privacy issues and the role of the judiciary.
=== EPIC Consumer Privacy project === The [https://epic.org/privacy/consumer/ EPIC Consumer Privacy Project] advocates for the rights consumers and Internet users, and works to protect consumers' personal information and autonomy in the digital marketplace. EPIC promotes the implementation and enforcement of Fair Information Practices, and the enactment of the Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights, so that consumers do not have to choose between engaging in modern society and retaining their right to privacy.
=== EPIC Domestic Surveillance project === EPIC's [https://epic.org/privacy/surveillance Domestic Surveillance Project] focuses public attention on merging technologies used to conduct domestic surveillance. As federal Judge Chutkan explained in a case brought by EPIC, "There can be little dispute that the general public has a genuine, tangible interest in a system designed to store and manipulate significant quantities of its own biometric data, particularly given the great numbers of people from whom such data will be gathered."
EPIC's Domestic Surveillance Project looks also at drone surveillance, social media monitoring, police body-worn cameras, passenger profiling, [[vehicle tracking system|vehicle tracking]] and [[cyber-surveillance]]. The Project pursues several activities to inform the public and to advocate for better privacy protections. EPIC uses FOIA to obtain documents about government surveillance programs. EPIC also files comments with federal agencies, leads coalition advocacy efforts, and testifies before state and federal legislatures for better privacy protections. EPIC has filed numerous amicus briefs in important court cases that address surveillance issues.
=== EPIC Administrative Law project === Through the [https://epic.org/apa/comments/ Administrative Law Project], EPIC aims to compel federal agencies to adopt practices that safeguard privacy and promote transparency. EPIC has pursued this mission through extensive comments to agencies, and subsequent lawsuits in instances where agencies fail to adopt EPIC's recommendations. Over the last twenty years, EPIC has successfully advocated for individual privacy rights in agency rulemaking proceedings. EPIC has also successfully sued the government to force an agency to conduct a public rulemaking as required under the APA.
==Publications and web sites== EPIC maintains and publishes its newsletter, the ''EPIC Alert'', every two weeks.
EPIC also publishes several books on privacy and open government, including ''Privacy in the Modern Age: The Search for Solutions, Privacy Law Sourcebook, Privacy and Human Rights, Litigation Under the Federal Open Government Laws, Filters and Freedom, The Public Voice WSIS Sourcebook,'' and ''The Consumer Law Sourcebook''.
EPIC maintains web sites for the Privacy Coalition, the Public Voice coalition, and the National Committee for Voting Integrity.

{{Infobox person | pre-nominals = Doctor | name = Ernest Madu | image = | caption = Prof. Ernest Madu accepts Award for Excellence in Civic Leadership circa 2016 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|02|18}} | occupation = Cardiologist and Entrepreneur | title = Chairman and Founder of The Heart Institute of the Caribbean Managing Partner of IHS Group USA }}
'''Dr. Ernest Madu''' (born February 18, 1960) is a nuclear cardiologist whose work focuses on providing affordable public healthcare in low-resource nations.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.masterspublichealth.net/30-most-influential-people-in-public-health/|title=The 30 Most Influential People in Public Health|website=www.masterspublichealth.net|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-17}}</ref> As founder, chairman, and CEO of the [[Heart Institute of the Caribbean (HIC)]],<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pennmedicine.org/news/news-releases/2016/september/penn-center-for-global-health|title=Penn Center for Global Health Announces Inaugural Global Health Champion Award Winner – PR News|website=www.pennmedicine.org|access-date=2018-01-17}}</ref> Dr. Madu’s research concentrates on the management and health effects of globalization in susceptible populations.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.caribbeanheart.com/profiles-madu.php|title=Heart Institute of the Caribbean - Profiles|website=www.caribbeanheart.com|access-date=2018-01-17}}</ref> Dr. Richard Chazal, President of the [[American College of Cardiology]], noted that Dr. Madu has made "great contributions to the College and to the international cardiovascular community."<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/heart-institute-founder-receives-prestigious-distinguished-award-from-the-american-college-of-cardiology-300444314.html|title=Heart Institute Founder Receives Prestigious Distinguished Award From The American College Of Cardiology|last=Caribbean|first=Heart Institute of the|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-17}}</ref> While [[TED (conference)|TED]] notes that “Dr. Madu’s research on noninvasive evaluation of coronary artery disease in obese individuals has become a standard evaluating tool” in the world of medicine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ted.com/speakers/ernest_madu|title=Ernest Madu {{!}} Speaker {{!}} TED|last=Madu|first=Ernest|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en}}</ref>
== Honors and awards == Extramural honors and awards include: * Named among the "''100 Most Influential People in Healthcare''" by Grupo Mídia at its awards ceremony held in [[Düsseldorf|Dusseldorf, Germany]], at MEDICA 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/news/20171206/dr-ernest-madu-named-one-most-influential-people-healthcare|title=Dr Ernest Madu named one of the most influential people in healthcare|website=jamaica-gleaner.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-18}}</ref> * ''Distinguished Award (International Service)'' from the [[American College of Cardiology|American College of Cardiology (ACC)]]. The award was presented at the Convocation of the College’s 66th Annual Scientific Session in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington, D.C]]., March 2017.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.acc.org/membership/member-benefits-and-resources/award-programs/acc-distinguished-awards-program/2017-distinguished-awardees|title=2017 Distinguished Awardees - American College of Cardiology|website=American College of Cardiology|access-date=2018-01-18}}</ref> * ''Global Health Champion Award'', 2016, [[University of Pennsylvania]] [[Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania|Perelman School of Medicine]], USA.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.drasatrust.org/ghchampion-award/|title=Global Health Champion Award: Dr. Ernest Madu|date=2016-09-19|work=Dr. Ameyo Stella Adadevoh (DRASA) Health Trust|access-date=2018-01-19|language=en-US}}</ref> * Named among “''30 Most Influential in Public Health''” by Masters Public Health, 2014.<ref name=":0" /> * ''Nation Builder Award'' from [[National Commercial Bank of Jamaica|National Commercial Bank (NCB)]]. The award was presented at the NCB’s annual national awards programme for Small and Medium Enterprises, October 2014.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://anpa.org/2016/10/29/ernest-madu-and-hic-recognized-at-the-amcham-business-and-civic-leadership-awards-for-excellence-2016/|title=Ernest Madu and HIC Recognized at The AMCHAM Business and Civic Leadership Awards for Excellence 2016 – ANPA|website=anpa.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> * ''Innovation Award'' from National Commercial Bank (NCB). The award was presented at the NCB’s annual national awards programme for Small and Medium Enterprises, October 2014.<ref name=":3" /> * ''Corporate Social Responsibility Award'' ''for a Small Organization'' from AMCHAM Jamaica. The award was presented at the AMCHAM Business and Civic Leadership Awards for Excellence 2016, October 2015 <ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Nominations-close-for-AmCham-s-Oct-21-awards_77340|title=Nominations close for AmCham’s Oct 21 awards|last=Limited|first=Jamaica Observer|website=Jamaica Observer|access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> * ''Corporate Social Responsibility Award for a Small Organization'' from AMCHAM Jamaica. The award was presented at the AMCHAM Business and Civic Leadership Awards for Excellence 2016, October 2016 <ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> * ''Civic Leadership Individual Award'' from AMCHAM Jamaica. The award was presented at the AMCHAM Business and Civic Leadership Awards for Excellence 2016, October 2016 <ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Big-names-nominated-for-AMCHAM-Awards_76594|title=Big names nominated for AMCHAM Awards|last=Limited|first=Jamaica Observer|website=Jamaica Observer|access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>

{{italic title}} [[File:William Hogarth - The Five Orders of Perriwigs.png|thumb|400px|''The Five Orders of Perriwigs as they were Worn at the Late Coronation Measured Architectonically'', [[William Hogarth]], 1761.]]
The '''''Five Orders of Periwigs''''' (''The Five Orders of Perriwigs as they were Worn at the Late Coronation Measured Architectonically'') is a 1761 engraving by [[William Hogarth]]. It contains several levels of [[satire]]. First, and most clearly, it [[parody|lampoon]]s the fashion for outlandish [[wig]]s in the mid to late 18th century. Second, in classifying the wigs into "orders", it satirises the formulation of canons of beauty from the analysis of surviving pieces of [[classical architecture]] and [[classical sculpture|sculpture]] from [[ancient Greece]] and [[ancient Rome]], particularly the precise drawings of [[James Stuart (1713-1788)|James "Athenian" Stuart]] (published in the ''Antiquities of Athens'', the first volume of which appeared in 1762). To the lower right, the engraving gives its publication date as 15 October 1761.
Of the engraving, Hogarth himself commented in his book of anecdotes:
:''There is no great difficulty in measuring the length, breadth, or height of any figures, where the parts are made up of plain lines. It requires no more skill to take the dimensions of a pillar or cornice, than to measure a square box, and yet the man who does the latter is neglected, and he who accomplishes the former, is considered as a miracle of genius; but I suppose he receives his honours for the distance he has travelled to do his business.''
As a parallel to the [[Classical order|five orders]] of [[classical architecture]] identified by [[Palladio]] ([[Doric order|Doric]], [[Ionic order|Ionic]], [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]], [[Composite order|Composite]] and [[Tuscan order|Tuscan]]), the engraving postulates five "orders" of periwig, from the relatively simple "Episcopal" (for the clergy), through the "Old Peerian or Aldermanic" (for lords and council officials) and "Lexonic" (for lawyers) to the more ornate "Composite or Half Natural", and finally the effete "Queerinthian or [[Queue (hairstyle)|Queue]] de [[Reynard]]" (a pun on the French for "foxtail").
A scale shows the "Athenian Measure" by which the dimensions of each wig are annotated, with one "nodule" comprising 3 "nasos" (noses) and each "naso" of 3 "minutes". The component parts of each wig are labelled with letters A to I, each denoting a mock architectural terms, from A: the "Corona or Lermier or Foretop" and B: the "Architrave or Archivolt or Caul" to H: "Fillet or Ribbon" and I: "Helices or Volute or Spiral or Curl".
Several of the faces depicted have been identified. Those in the Episcopal line are intended to resemble Doctor [[William Warburton]], [[Bishop of Gloucester]] (left) and Doctor [[Samuel Squire]], [[Bishop of St David's]] (right). In the "Old Peerian or Aldermanic" row are [[George Dodington, 1st Baron Melcombe|Lord Melcombe]] (left) and another. The wig depicted to the far right is a "remarkable winged periwig" worn by [[Sir Samuel Fludyer, 1st Baronet]] when he became [[Lord Mayor of London]] earlier in 1761.
At the bottom of the engraving is an inscription stating that a series of six folio volumes published over 17 years will set out the measurements of the periwigs of the ancients. This satirises Stuart's ''Antiquities of Athens''. Above, a line of female profiles shows, from left to right, the face of [[Queen Charlotte]] and five others, each wearing a triple necklace and bearing a [[coronet]]: a [[duchess]], a [[marchioness]], a [[countess]], a [[viscountess]], and a [[baroness]]. They have been alternatively identified as the [[Ladies of the Bedchamber]] in 1761 - the [[Duchess of Ancaster]], [[Elizabeth Campbell, 1st Baroness Hamilton of Hameldon|Duchess of Hamilton]], [[Elizabeth Howard, Countess of Effingham|Countess of Effingham]], [[Elizabeth Percy, Duchess of Northumberland|Countess of Northumberland]], [[Elizabeth Thynne, Viscountess Weymouth|Viscountess Weymouth]], and [[Diana St John, Viscountess Bolingbroke|Viscountess Bolingbroke]].
Hogarth created the engraving a few weeks after the [[coronation]] of [[George III]] and [[Queen Charlotte]], inspired by the elaborate costume worn by those who attended. [[Horace Walpole]] wrote: "Some of the peeresses were dressed over night, slept in armchairs, and were waked if they tumbled their heads".
A number of spelling mistakes were noted in the first state of the engraving ("{{sic|advertisement|hide=y}}", "{{sic|volumns|hide=y}}"). A second [[state (printmaking)|state]] of the engraving corrects a typographical error by inserting the letter "e" in "{{sic|advertisement|hide=y}}", and relabels the "Episcopal" order of periwigs as "Episcopal and Parsonic".
==References== *[http://www.artoftheprint.com/artistpages/hogarth_william_five_orders_perriwigs.htm Artoftheprint.com] *[https://books.google.com/books?id=2xIEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA256&lpg=PA256&dq=five+orders+of+periwigs&source=bl&ots=U1yqCy5TSH&sig=Ta3IS_vqQQlRavHC6Vtc00tvx84&hl=en&ei=j1ELSvGdMNGSjAeq-5CxCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3 ''Anecdotes of William Hogarth: written by himself'', William Hogarth, 1833, p.256-258] *[https://www.google.com/books?id=UucDZXpSQLIC&pg=RA1-PA373&dq=Five+Orders+of+Perriwigs&as_brr=1#PRA1-PA373,M1 ''Biographical Anecdotes of William Hogarth'', John Nichols, 1785, 0.373-374]
{{William Hogarth}}

{{main|Gender Inequality}}
'''Gender inequality in the English Caribbean''' refers to gaps between individuals based on gender in the Anglophone countries of the [[Commonwealth Caribbean|Caribbean]]. These gaps persist in the areas of human and physical capital endowments, in economic opportunities, and in the ability to make choices to achieve desired outcomes (agency).<ref>The World Bank. 2012. Gender Equality and Development: World Development Report 2012. Washington, D.C: The World Bank.p.5</ref>
Caribbean countries have been moving toward compliance with the [[United Nation]]'s Convention on the Elimination on Discrimination Against Women ([[CEDAW]]), but according to the UN Women Caribbean department, there is still work to be done to achieve gender equality in the region.<ref name = unwomen>Women's Empowerment and Gender Equality in the Caribbean. Advocacy Brief. http://www.unifemcar.org/ge_iss.cfm?link_=13(Accessed Apr 9, 2012).</ref> In the English speaking Caribbean, women are disadvantaged in the labor market as well as the legislature, whereas men and boys face unequal outcomes in education.<ref name= caricomgender>CARICOM Secretariat, "Plan of Action for 2005: Framework for Mainstreaming Gender into Key CARICOM Programmes" Andaiye, Georgetown, 2003. part IV.</ref> [[Amartya Sen]]’s [[capabilities approach]] asserts that all inequalities, including those relating to gender, keep individuals from securing opportunities and choosing from these opportunities to achieve desired outcomes.
==Background== The [[Caribbean]] is made of the chain of islands that border the [[Caribbean Sea]] and the [[Atlantic Ocean]]. The region also includes mainland regions such as [[Guyana]] who identify culturally and historically with those island. The Caribbean region is made up of many developing nations. Most of the islands of the English-speaking Caribbean have less than a century of independence from [[colonialism]] and, by the world’s standards, their governments are fairly young. In recent decades the world has seen significant changes in GDPs and other economic and globalization factors leading to increased inequality within and between countries.<ref name= feminist>Berik, Günseli, Yana van der Meulen Rodgers, and Stephanie Seguino. 2009. “Feminist Economics of Inequality, Development, and Growth.” Feminist Economics. p.1.</ref> “In the last ten to fifteen years the Latin American and Caribbean region has undergone the most significant changes of economic policy since World War II.”<ref name= equity>Peres, Wilson. Stallings, Barbara. Growth, Unemployment and Equity. The Impact of Economic Reforms in Latin America and the Caribbean. Brookings Institution Press: Washington D.C. 200. P.1.</ref> Many of these policies were expected to create new jobs and greater equality.<ref name= equity/> Still “people in Latin America and the Caribbean region face unequal opportunities in life and different chances of economic success and very unequal outcomes ”<ref>Barros, Ricardo Paes. et al. Measuring Inequality of Opportunities in Latin America and the Caribbean. Palgrave Macmillan and The World Bank. 2009. P. 26</ref> Areas such as education, labor and politics are just a few but important areas in which gender inequality is apparent in the region. Growing GDPs and globalization however, are not enough to offset the effect of [[gender inequality]].<ref name= feminist/> With the exception of education women bear most of the negative impacts that occur as a result of gender inequality in the Caribbean region.<ref name= Bailey>Barbara Bailey and Heather Ricketts . “Gender Vulnerabilities in Caribbean Labor Markets and Decent Work Provisions.” Social and Economic Studies , Vol. 52, No. 4. P.56-58. University of the West Indies. https://www.jstor.org/stable/27865353 . (Accessed on Mar 15th 2012).</ref>
==Labor and migration== Women in the Caribbean make up a significant number of the labor force but still earn significantly less than their male counterparts. On average, 50 percent of women are a part of the formal sector as compared to more than 75 percent of men.<ref name= Bailey/>
===Unemployment=== Unemployment rates are high throughout the region. According to the Central Intelligence Agency ([[CIA]]), the unemployment rates in [[Antigua and Barbuda]] are at 11 percent (2001 est), about 23 percent (2000 est) in [[Dominica]], 20 percent in [[Saint Lucia]] (2003 est), and 25 percent in [[Grenada]].<ref>Central Intelligence Acency. The World Factbook Online. https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/index.html (Accessed on Apr 9, 2012)</ref> Unemployment rates are especially high for women despite their higher educational attainment.<ref name= Bailey/> According to the World Development Report of 2007/2008 the fe[[male unemployment]] rate in [[Jamaica]] is 207 percent of the [[male unemployment]] rate, in Guyana that number is 240 percent, in St. Lucia 164 percent, and 190 percent in Trinidad and Tobago.<ref>Human Development Report. 2007-2008. United Nations Development Programme. New York 2007. p.299.</ref>
===Informal work=== [[Informal sector|Informal work]], as defined by [[Martha Chen]], is work that may be unpaid or work that is simply not a part of the formal legal structure.<ref>Chen, Martha, Joann Vanek, Francie Lund, James Heintz with Renana Jhabvala, and Christine Bonner. 2005. “The Totality of Women’s Work,” in Progress of the World’s Women, pp. 22–35. New York: United Nations Development Fund for Women.</ref> Many women and men in the Caribbean region are engaged on a large scale in the [[informal sector]]. Within the informal sector however, there is earning discrimination.<ref name= Bailey1>Barbara Bailey and Heather Ricketts . “Gender Vulnerabilities in Caribbean Labor Markets and Decent Work Provisions.” Social and Economic Studies , Vol. 52, No. 4. P.74-56. University of the West Indies. https://www.jstor.org/stable/27865353 . (Accessed on Mar 15th 2012).</ref> Men tend to do the work that earns high wages whereas women do the work that is considered domestic.<ref name= caricomgender/> Within the informal sector women earn less wages than men.<ref name= Bailey1/> This has important implications for the region because most households are headed by women who are the sole breadwinners.<ref name= household>Sheila Stuart, "Female-Headed Families: A Comparative Perspective of the Caribbean and the Developed World" Gender and Development , Vol. 4, No. 2 (Jun., 1996), pp. 28.</ref> This may also contribute to the poverty gender bias in the region.<ref name= Caricom>Caribbean Community Secretariat. http://www.caricom.org/jsp/speeches/cag_conference_barnett.jsp?null&prnf=1 (accessed on March 20, 2012).</ref> Informal work does not provide benefits such as healthcare and are especially vulnerable to economic shifts and natural disasters.<ref name= Bailey1/> Women in this region have less access to credit and other avenues that would allow them to enter the formal sector, therefore, many of their businesses, such as shop keeping, belong to the informal sector.<ref name= Bailey/> Occupations such as inter island trade are largely unprotected.<ref name= Bailey1/> There are no assurances for healthcare, pregnancy leave, or sick leave.<ref name= Bailey1/>
===Formal work=== Moves have been made at decreasing the gender bias in labor. Caribbean countries have put in place minimum wage levels as well as paternity and maternity leave.<ref name= unwomen/> In this region many of the men employed in the formal sector are less qualified than their female counterparts and in fact, many are under-qualified.<ref name= Bailey/> As a result men are given more opportunities for onsite and occupational training. Women in the formal sector work less hours and earn lower wages.<ref name= Bailey/> The [[Inter-American Development Bank]] reports that at every educational level, men earn higher wages than women.<ref name= iadb>Annelle Bellony, Alejandro Hoyos, Hugo Ñopo. "Gender Earning Gaps in the Caribbean: Evidence from Barbados and Jamaica" Aug 2010. Inter-American Development Bank.p.9</ref> The wage levels for women with none, primary, and secondary education are similar.<ref name= iadb/> Women only see significant changes in their wages with tertiary education.<ref name= iadb/> This is not the case for men.<ref name= iadb/>
Cultural norms place the burden of [[care work]] and household work on women. Therefore, women are often forced into occupations that require them to reconcile their home responsibilities with their jobs.<ref name= Caricom/> Many of the women who are employed within the formal sector, work as professionals which is a testament to their higher educational attainment.<ref name= Bailey/> Still, there are fewer women in the workforce and they earn less than their male counterparts.<ref name= Bailey/>
===Migration=== Within the Caribbean region, significant portions of the population participate in extra- and to a lesser extent, intra- regional migration. According to the [[World Bank]], between 1989 and 2001, over 1.4 million Caribbean nationals migrated legally to the U.S.<ref>Josefina Stubbs and Hiska Reyes, "Migration and the Caribbean: A Path to Development?" The World Bank,2004. p.1</ref> Migration, especially for economic reasons, also has a significant gender impact. Since the 1960s more West Indian women than West Indian men migrated to the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom.<ref>Suzanne Model. 1995. “West Indian Prosperity: Fact or Fiction?” University of California Press. P.238. https://www.jstor.org/stable/3097045 (accessed on March 14, 2012).</ref> Professionals, particularly those skilled in Health and Education, have moved out of the region in large numbers.<ref>United Nations Secretariat, "Migration in the Caribbean –What Do We Know?" ECLAC. 2006.p.1</ref> Women often migrate with the hope of having their family follow years later or making enough money to provide stable lives for their families back home. The major migration of women out of the Caribbean region has a tremendous impact on a region known to have notoriously low marriage rates, and in which many households are headed by women.<ref>Seager, Joni. 2008. The Penguin Atlas of Women in the World. 4th ed. New York: Penguin Books.</ref> Many families construct extended family units in which childcare and housework are split among the women.<ref>Aymer Paula. "Caribbean women: Labor Migrants and Traders." Ahfad Journal 22, no. 1 (June 2005): 97-108. Academic Search Complete, EBSCOhost (accessed March 19, 2012).</ref>
===Migrant nurses=== Migrant nursing programs find a large pool of recruits from the Caribbean. Traditionally nurses in the region were almost exclusively women. There are a substantial number of nurses from the Anglophone Caribbean working in the United States and an even greater number in the United Kingdom.<ref name= nurse>Jones, A.D., A. Bifulco, and J. Gabe. 2009. "Caribbean nurses migrating to the UK: a gender-focused literature review." International Nursing Review 56, no. 3: 285-290. Academic Search Complete, EBSCOhost (accessed March 18, 2012).</ref> Since 1980 as many as one third of Caribbean nurses are thought to have migrated. This has major implications for primary care facilities, such as health centers which rely on the region’s nurses.<ref name= nurse/>
==Family life== The burden of [[care work]] (childcare, elderly care, and care for the sick) housework falls disproportionately on women in the Caribbean.<ref name= unwomenpoverty>UN Women Caribbean, "Strengthening Women's Economic Security and Rights." http://www.unifemcar.org/ge_iss.cfm?SubID=168&link_=1.(Accessed Apr 14, 2012).</ref> Within the region there is little to no provision for free childcare so this burden has severe implications for women.<ref name= caricomgender/> Social norms permit women to work for the sustainment of their families, but also carries expectations about family life and customs, that favor men as breadwinners and women as homemakers.<ref name= Bailey/> This is a surprising fact considering that women in the Caribbean have worked outside the home since the days of slavery, through indenture, and on through independence.<ref name= caricomgender/> These norms have a negative effect on the region because most households are headed by a sole female provider.<ref name= household/> Family life, child care, and elderly care often shapes women's wage work, constraining them to places near the home.<ref name= caricomgender/>
===Marriage=== Within the region, marriage rates are low.<ref>Joni Seager,"The Penguin Atlas of Women in the World." Penguin Books, New York, 2009. p.24</ref> [[common-law marriage|Common-law relationships]] are common as well as visiting relationships where one partner lives or works in another country or at another primary residence.<ref name= household/> The general expectation throughout the region is that women remain monogamous whereas it is more acceptable for men to have multiple partners.<ref name =caricomgender/> It is common for men to have multiple families.<ref name= caricomgender/>
===Domestic violence=== Violence against women is widespread throughout the region. According to UN Women Caribbean, 1 in 3 women in the Caribbean will experience domestic violence.<ref name= unwomenviolence>UN Women Caribbean, "Ending Violence against Women." http://www.unifemcar.org/ge_iss.cfm?SubID=169&link_=12. (Accessed on Apr 14,2012.)</ref> Three Caribbean countries are among the top 10 for reported incidence of rape, and all Caribbean countries have higher than the world average for rape.<ref name= unwomenviolence/> The devaluation of [[women's work]], decreases their bargaining power within the home and this leads to widespread partner violence.<ref name= caricomgender/> Both women and girls are affected by violence. A large percentage of girls report forced sexual initiation.<ref name= unwomenviolence/>
Most of the countries in the region have now fully criminalized rape within marriage and have added measure that give women full access to courts for orders of protection.<ref name= unwomenviolence/> [[Partnership for Peace]], UN Trust Fund to End Violence Against Women, and other organizations are all working to end violence against women in region.
==Education== The countries of the Caribbean have a history of universal access to [[Primary school|primary education]] and widely available [[secondary school]]ing. The Caribbean however, paints a different picture of gender and education than most of the other places in the world.<ref name= school>Kutnick, P., Jules, V., Layne, A., & Department for International Development, L. ). (1997). Gender and School Achievement in the Caribbean. Education Research Paper. P.9-15, 143.</ref> Throughout the entire Caribbean girls outperform boys during primary school, specifically in the areas of mathematics, English and reading. On the [[Caribbean Examination Council]] (CXC) exam, taken near the end of secondary school, girls were both more likely to score better than boys as well as outperform them across all subject areas.<ref name= school/> Reports have found that both the education of children’s parents and their presence at home were significant in predicting children’s attainment in school. This was especially true for fathers and male students who performed better when their fathers were both better educated and present in the home.<ref name= school/> Boys were more likely than girls to drop out before and during secondary school. Boys also had higher repetition rates.<ref>Druyea, S. (Sonstige beteiligte Personen), Galiani, S. (Sonstige beteiligte Personen), Ñopo, H. (Sonstige beteiligte Personen), & Piras, C. (Sonstige beteiligte Personen). (2007). The educational gender gap in Latin America and the Caribbean. Washington, DC.</ref> Women completed on average 13.3 years of schooling whereas their male counterparts completed 12.7 years. Women are enrolled in secondary and tertiary levels in greater numbers than men.<ref name= politics>Presence Without Empowerment? Women in Politics in Latin America and the Caribbean. SSRC Conflict Prevention and Peace Forum. http://webarchive.ssrc.org/pdfs/Mala_Htun_and_Jennifer_M._Piscopo-Presence_without_Empowerment_CPPF_Briefing_Paper_Dec_2010_f.pdf (accessed on March 26, 2012).</ref>
==Politics== Women in the English speaking Caribbean gained the right to vote in their independent legislatures at the same time as men. The percentage of women who turn out to vote is similar to that of men however, women are significantly underrepresented in the island legislatures.
===Legislation=== Women make up 15 percent of the islands' legislators. Within the region, the higher a country’s GDP the more likely of women holding cabinet ministries. However women’s higher educational attainment throughout the region does not correlate with higher representation within government.<ref name=politics/> Female ministers are more likely to head ministries traditionally associated with women such as, Education, Tourism, Housing and Culture.<ref name=politics/> [[Dominica]], [[Guyana]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]], and [[Jamaica]] have all seen women Prime Ministers or heads of state. Women in the region are largely underrepresented in politics. Jamaica's most former Prime Minister was a woman, the Honourable [[Portia Simpson-Miller]]. The Honorable [[Kamla Persad-Bissessar]] was the female Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago from May 26th 2010 to September 9th 2015.<ref>Caricom Leaders Hail Region’s Women. http://www.caricom.org/jsp/pressreleases/press_releases_2012/pres64_12.jsp (Accessed on March 25, 2012)</ref> This is significant because these two islands have the largest GDPs in the English speaking Caribbean region. ====Dame Mary Eugenia Charles==== {{main|Eugenia Charles}}
Born May 15, 1919 [[Dame Eugenia Charles]] rose up to be the first female Prime Minister in the Caribbean and the first female Head of State in the Americas to be elected in her own right. Born on the island of [[Dominica]], she went on to study economics in Canada and the [[London School of Economics]]. She then moved back to her native [[Dominica]] as the first female lawyer on the island. She opened a law firm but soon found herself active in politics.<ref name=Charles>Colquhoun, Keith, and Ann Wroe. "Eugenia Charles." Economist Book of Obituaries, October 2008., 64-65, Business Source Complete, EBSCOhost (accessed April 1, 2012).</ref> In 1968 she opposed the [[Dominica Labour Party]]’s attempt to pass the Sedition Acts. She was appointed to the Legislature and the Assembly in 1970 and 1975 respectively. In 1972 she help found the [[Dominica Freedom Party]] which helped Dominica gain independence from the British Crown on November 3, 1978.<ref name=Charles1>Dame Mary Eugenia Charles. {{cite web |url=http://www.caricom.org/jsp/projects/personalities/dame_mary.jsp?menu=projects |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-09-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610033648/http://www.caricom.org/jsp/projects/personalities/dame_mary.jsp?menu=projects |archivedate=2007-06-10 |df= }} (accessed March 25, 2012).</ref> After the devastation of [[Hurricane David]] in 1979 Charles’ plan for reconstruction helped her sweep the 1980 election. She led her country from 1980 to 1995 and became known as “The Iron Lady of the Caribbean.”<ref name= Charles/> Charles gained popularity on the world stage in 1983, when she encouraged the United States, under President Ragan, to invade [[Grenada]] after Cuban rebels had taken hold.<ref name= Charles/>
Charles’ work in the area of reform, economics and Caribbean integration is notable. In 1991 Mary Eugenia Charles was knighted by Queen Elizabeth 11.<ref name= Charles1/> Dame Eugenia Charles put in place the Women's Desk in her native Dominica and after her election it evolved into the Women's Bureau.<ref name= desk>The Women's Bureau, "Dominica's Report on the Outcome of the Twenty-Third Special Session of the General Assembly", un.org, 2004.</ref> This department provided for a more systematic involvement of women in development and was the first in the region.<ref name= desk/>
Dame Eugenia Charles died on September 6, 2005.
==Poverty==
Poverty in the English Caribbean affects both men and women. The combination of the burden of care work and lack of opportunity in the labor market for women translates into poverty having a very gendered impact in the region.<ref name= caricomgender/> Women have limited access to resources, such as land and especially credit.<ref name="unwomenpoverty" /> Like the other factors, this is significant in a region where a majority of the households are headed solely by women.<ref name= household/> In islands like [[St. Vincent and the Grenadines]] and across the region women head 96 percent of all poor households.<ref name= unwomenpoverty/><ref name= goals>CARICOM Secretariat "Gender and the Millennium Development Goals: More Specific Targets and Indicators For the Caribbean." Task force on gender and poverty, 2005.</ref> In Dominica, where the number of poor men and women is almost equal (about 28.8 percent), only 20 percent of the male poor population is unemployed whereas 33.8 percent of poor women are unemployed.<ref>Government of Dominca, "Country Poverty Assesmet: Dominica 2008/2009" Kairi Consultations Lmtd, Trinidad, 2009. Table 6.7</ref> In St. Lucia as with many other countries, women in the lowest socio-economic bracket were very likely to have their first birth during their teen years.<ref>Government of St. Lucia, "St. Lucia Country Poverty Assessment 2005/2006" Kairi Consultations Lmmtd, Trinidad 2006. Table 4.13</ref>
==Progress==
Over the past decade, the English speaking Caribbean, under the lead of the Caribbean Community ([[CARICOM]]), has made significant strides in improving gender parity.<ref name= unwomen/> The United Nations Women Caribbean is also working to reach gender equity in the region.<ref name= goals/> The CARICOM Secretariat and the United Nations Development Fund for women ([[UNIFEM]]) formed a task force in 2005 charged with identifying region specific indicators for reaching the UN's development goals.<ref name= goals/>
The [[Caribbean Association for Feminist Research and Action]] (CAFRA), has worked to end violence against women and to secure sex workers rights.<ref name= unwomenequality>UN Women Caribbean "Women's Empowerment and Gender Equality in the Caribbean." http://www.unifemcar.org/ge_iss.cfm?link_=13 (Accessed on Apr 16 2012)</ref> Individual countries have committed to putting in place women's councils. Dominica has had the Dominica National Council of women, which "aims to sensitize, empower, and unite women and their families."<ref> The Dominica National Council of Women "Report for Presentation to the Banana Crisis Conference" since 1995.</ref> Moves are being made within the entire region to improve education for young men, to improve representation of women in the legislature, to improve their conditions in the workforce and to relieve the burden of care work.<ref name= goals/>
